comment.author: 58930216@N04

comment._content: St Joseph's RC Church (not in this photo?) was built in 1879.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] That's it alright. Well done.

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content:
Ah yes of course, it's the old St Joseph's Industrial School at Clifden.......

Sadly, it was to become notorious with certain activity which we should not discuss here, suffice to say that at least one member of staff spent a considerable time in custody for his part in that activity.... Enough said about that!

Perhaps the unfortunate legacy of this institution is the reason for the attempt to make it unidentifiable?

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The building with the chapel appears to be St. Josephs industrial school, 1872 - 1983, so it's post 1872.

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: St Joseph's Industrial School was founded in 1861.... with the first phase of the building constructed in 1862.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: If anyone knows anything about RIC uniforms you could probably date it from the funny hats.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Well done all of you! Perfect Street View comparison from MKSeery! But before ye abandon ship, what about a date?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Railway started 1895 - so prior to this date

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: No sign of St. Josephs RC Church in this one, and I think it should be visible if built. From the DIA: Name: O'CALLAGHAN, JOHN JOSEPH Building: CO. GALWAY, CLIFDEN, CHURCH OF ST JOSEPH (RC) Date: 1871-74;1898 Nature: New church. Tenders invited, Dec 1871. FS laid 28 Aug 1872 by Archbishop MacHale. Builder: P. Morris. Building in advanced state of progress by Oct 1874. Tower and spire added 1898 through exertions of Canon Lynskey, PP (tenders sought May, 1896,Jun 1898).

comment.author: 65105123@N06
comment._content: The Mark IIa Newfoundland dog was not made until 1880 and discontinued after WW1, if that's any help...

comment.author: 58930216@N04
comment._content: Somewhere between 1862 & 1870, it has to be....

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It appears from Danny's map that the building with the chapel is the convent and the building on the far side of the courthouse is the industrial school, which would make it post 1872.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: But we know it's before October 1874, when the colossal church was at an advanced stage of building. I think that field between the camera and convent would be a building site from August 1872, the laying of the foundation stone.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The convent itself was from 1855, and the courthouse 1840, no help.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Well, you've got it down to two years then. Do you want me to go mad with the solar calculator and give you a date as well?

comment.author: 29492435@N02

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
Lunchtime at the end of april or the middle of august. I'd have guessed april from the bare branches but it looks quite warm from the posture of the three lads on the wall. Maybe people were just tougher in those days.
This is based on the courthouse which we know faces due south. I think the sun's about 10 degrees east of south and about 50 degrees above the horizon.

comment.author: 8468254@N02

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] If you took a picture where I am today (south Dublin) and your great grandson looked at it in 100 years, he would conclude sometime between December 10th and February 2nd..........when will this weather improve!!!!!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: If it wasn't pissing rain the whole summer I'd probably drop by for a visit. I might check out their online archive and see if I can get a match.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I'm not sure it matches any of these. The hat seems to have an overhanging top as well as a brim, but it's too tall to be the back right one. I guess this means it's pre-1882. www.nmni.com/Home/Shop/Products/Photographs/Green-Collect...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: As far as I can tell from images on the web, up to about 1868, they all had pickelhaubes, and by 1880, they all had pillboxes which were then replaced by a hat like the modern garda hat, and in between, there was 12 years of undatable mayhem. But the main problem appears to be that in 1870, policemen weren't interesting enough to photograph.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I had a look again at the original super duper high res image and they look most like "a hat like the modern garda hat" as you say. Flat top and definitely a shiny peak over the forehead as both are reflecting the light. Interestingly, the chap on the left seems to have a beard. I think one of our photos had input on facial hair in the police... Ah yes, it's this one!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: If the chap on the right doesn't also have a beard then he's got a very high collar.
